title: UCLA Bruins Coach Blasts Reporters in Most Polite Way Possible
description: UCLA Bruins coach Deshaun Foster took aim at the media, but did it politely.
content:
Based on facts, either observed and verified firsthand by the reporter, or reported and verified from knowledgeable sources.

The UCLA Bruins' football program has long been a struggling entity, participating in just two bowl games since 2018. Last year, UCLA went just 5-7 in Deshaun Foster's debut as head coach, so now, Foster is attempting to change things up.

Foster has taken a rather firm stance in limiting media availability to his team this season, restricting reporters from access to Bruins practices and even player interviews.

More news: Deion Sanders, Colorado May Have Found Their Travis Hunter Replacement

Recently, the former NFL running back was asked about his policy in a press conference, and he took the media to task in the most polite way you can imagine.

"Yeah, you guys film our practice and put it online," Foster said. "If I was an opponent for another team, I'd look right at your guys' stuff and see what's going on. ... That's why it's closed."

Foster added that player interviews are "the same thing" because it would lead to reporters then asking Foster follow-up questions on what the players said. He also said that he isn't worried about the marketing side of things because "if you win games, you're marketed."

Winning games isn't something UCLA did a whole lot of last year, but the Bruins did post three straight winning campaigns between 2021 and 2023. However, UCLA has not recorded a double-digit win season since 2014, and the school has only finished the season ranked in the top 25 once in the last decade.

Obviously, the Bruins are more known for their historic basketball program, but it's not like they are complete lightweights on the football circuit.

UCLA made the jump to the Big Ten last year, so the Bruins certainly have a tough 2025 schedule ahead of them. They currently have three ranked opponents on their slate, including matchups with No. 2 Penn State and No. 3 Ohio State.

We'll see if Foster's media strategy will end up paying off for UCLA.

For more on college football, head to Newsweek Sports.
summary: The UCLA Bruins football team has been struggling, having only played two bowl games since 2018 and only won five in their debut season under Deshaun Foster. The team has limited media availability to its own team this season and restricts reporters from access to Bruins practices and player interviews. During a recent press conference, Foster addressed reporters in a polite manner, stating that he is not concerned about the marketing implications as "if you win games, you're marketed." The Bruins have not recorded a double-digit win season since 2014 and have only finished the season ranked in the top 25 once in the last decade.
shortSummary: UCLA coach Deshaun Foster restricts media access to Bruins practices and player interviews, aiming to improve the team's performance and marketing reputation despite recent poor results.

The Texas Longhorns are everyone's college football darlings heading into the 2025 season. They are ranked No. 1 in the AP poll, and many are deeming them national championship favorites thanks much in part to Arch Manning's presence under center.
Based on the talent-laden roster, it's hard not to like Texas right now, but is it possible we are overrating the Longhorns?
More news: Clemson's Frustrating Transfer Portal Stance Lands Harsh Reality Check
The Athletic recently ran projections using a statistical model to determine how the college football landscape will shape up this year, and it does not seem to like Texas as much as you would think.
The Longhorns are the ninth-ranked team in the projections and are being predicted to finish with a record of 9-3. Two SEC teams — Georgia and Alabama — are ranked ahead of Texas, and the Longhorns are only being given a 64 percent chance of making the College Football Playoff.
We have seen this type of thing happen plenty of times before. Teams do get overhyped, and there actually are reasons to be worried about Texas going into the new campaign.
One of the biggest causes for concern is the Longhorns' offensive weapons, particularly in the receiving corps. Both Matthew Golden and Isaiah Bond made the jump to the NFL during the offseason, as did running back Jaydon Blue.
For as talented as Manning may be, it could be difficult for the young quarterback to overcome a dearth of proven weapons at his disposal, although there is also reason to believe that Texas may have a diamond in the rough. Stanford transfer Emmett Mosley V, for example, could comprise a breakout talent in Austin.
More news: Insider Reveals Major Red Flag for Clemson QB Cade Klubnik
Regardless, the Longhorns are certainly no shoo-in to make a deep playoff run, and they are not quite as loaded as last year's Ohio State Buckeyes squad, who defeated Texas in the Cotton Bowl en route to a national championship.
Ironically enough, the Longhorns will face Ohio State in their season opener next Saturday.

Deion Sanders and the Colorado Buffaloes were lucky enough to have a generational talent in their employ over the last couple of seasons, but now, Travis Hunter has departed for the NFL, leaving a gaping hole for Colorado on both sides of the ball.
Hunter played wide receiver and cornerback for the Buffaloes and managed to play both positions at an elite level, leading to the phenom being crowned the Heisman Trophy winner last year.
More news: Texas Longhorns Receive Concerning Prediction
But what will Sanders and Colorado do now that Hunter is no longer in Boulder? The Buffaloes will have to find a solution somewhere, but the good news is that they already may have an answer on their roster.
The Athletic recently published a piece in which it raved about a couple of transfers Colorado landed this offseason: running back Dekalon Taylor and wide receiver Sincere Brown. Both are viewed as explosive weapons, and while neither may exactly be as good as Hunter (few are), they could at least help fill the void.
"With projected starter Dallan Hayden expected to miss the game with a hand injury, Taylor, a 5-9, 165-pound former slot receiver from Incarnate Word, will get more work alongside sophomore Micah Welch," The Athletic wrote. "Taylor's breakaway speed has caught the attention of teammates in camp."
Taylor rushed for 909 yards and nine touchdowns on six yards per carry during his final season at Incarnate Word in 2024.
"Brown, a 6-5, 190-pound target, had a breakout 1,000-yard season at Campbell last fall and is expected to see a lot of snaps alongside Dre'lon Miller and Omarion Miller with three former starting receivers including Hunter off to the NFL," The Athletic concluded.
More news: Clemson's Frustrating Transfer Portal Stance Lands Harsh Reality Check
Taylor and Brown are certainly players to watch heading into the regular season and will be called upon to uplift a Colorado offense that not only lost Hunter, but also quarterback Shedeur Sanders and fellow receiver Jimmy Horn Jr.
Of course, Hunter is the most prominent weapon to replace, but perhaps someone like Taylor can step in and provide the Buffaloes with that game-breaking option. Then there is Brown, who should present a great red-zone target for Colorado this fall.

The Bruins, struggling to win games and recently moving to the Big Ten, face a tough 2025 schedule that includes ranked opponents like Penn State and Ohio State. Meanwhile, Texas is being questioned by projections as a playoff contender due to a lack of proven weapons, and Colorado is looking to fill the void left by Heisman winner Travis Hunter with new transfers Dekalon Taylor and Sincere Brown. The article highlights the challenges these programs face as they navigate media strategies, roster changes, and competitive schedules.
